   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for heart failure and new
   afib with RVR. She is improving after intubation requiring pressors and
   a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive
   cultures and a CT demonstrating diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary
   nodules.  Patient was extubated on [**12-17**], doing better from respiratory
   stand point, but likely need MVR for full recovery.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Patient is improving from respiratory stand
   point, CXR improbing as well.  RR remains in mid 20
s to upper 30
s on
   3L O2 by NC with adequate oxygenation all day yesterday. Patient
   received Lasix 120mg IV x 1 yesterday with resulting net negative
   780cc.  ABG reveals a mix picture of respiratory acidosis and metabolic
   alkalosis, likely from hypoventilation and overdiuresis/contraction
   alkalosis.  Although pt is improving from the respiratory stand point,
   it is unclear how well she can get without MVR surgery.
   - f/u Csurg recs
   - start lasix gtt today
   - keep HOB elevated, I/O goal of -500cc-1L
   - daily CXR
   - follow ABGs and respiratory status
   - continue standing Atrovent nebs
   - Complete Abx (Meropenem, Doxy, Acyclovir) regimen, finishing up
   meropenem today
   - continue TF
   - patient will need S/S re-eval tomorrow.  Currently aspirating.
   .
   # METABOLIC ALKALOSIS:  This is most likely contraction alkalosis due
   to overdiuresis.  BUN/Cr ratio is way above 20. No vomiting and loss of
   hydrogen ions from GI system.  No insulin or hypokalemia leading to
   alkalosis either.  Curiously, creatinine has been flat and even
   down-trending despite aggressive diuresis and contraction alkalosis.
   - get urine Cl to see if the metabolic alkalosis is chloride-responsive
   (if Ucl <10, responsive, if >20, not responsive)
   - slow down on diuresis given likely contraction alkalosis, start lasix
   gtt
   - I/O goal of -500cc-1L
   - pm lytes
   .
   # HYPERNATREMIA:  Na climbing to 149 today.  Also likely due to
   overdiuresis. Free water deficit is calculated to be 2.9L.
   - continue free water flushes 200cc q6h
   - slow down on diuresis given likely contraction alkalosis, start lasix
   gtt
   - I/O goal of -500cc-1L
   - pm lytes
   - f/u on nutrition recs on less concentrated TF
   .
   #. Fluid overload: Anasarca [**1-10**] fluid imbalance (multifactorial:
   hypoalbuminemia/chronic sCHF/
leaky capillary syndrome
), continues to
   improve. Patient continues to diurese well on IV Lasix.  Also with
   mildly elevated serum Na and HCO3 that may represent a contraction
   alkalosis.
   -  Goal diuresis is -0.5-1.0L today. Will exercise caution to maintain
   CVP ~ 10 & regulate electrolytes today.
   -  Closely monitor electrolytes and renal function [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Daily CXR
   -  CVP goal >10
   -  MAP goal is 60-65
   .
   # PUMP/SEVERE MR: History of chronic systolic heart failure, and
   patient
s initial sx were consistent with failure (SOB, orthopnea,
   edema), but TTE on admission showed normal EF (>60%). Patient also with
   known MR [**First Name (Titles) 43**] [**Last Name (Titles) 10178**] tear at posterior leaflet of mitral valve, likely
   contributing to worsening MR which causes overestimation of EF. Repeat
   TTE on [**12-16**] was unchanged from prior, but jet of MR was
better
   appreciated
 per interpretation.  Per Csurgery, no more pre-op testing
   is necessary until pt makes the decision to go for surgery.  Currently,
   patient is still leaning toward no surgery, but this may change as
   patient feels better.
   - need to get OSH dental records
   - f/u on carotid US final read.  The prelim read showed 0% stenosis.
   - continue to discuss surgical option with patient
   - F/U additional Csurg recs
   .
   # RHYTHM: Pt goes in and out of Afib.  Fluid shifts may be responsible,
   but MR is the main contributing factor although LA is not significantly
   dilated given prominent regurgitant jet.  TSH normal.
   - Continue PO Amiodarone 200mg [**Hospital1 **], will change to amiodarone 200mg
   daily tomorrow
   - Holding nodal agents in the setting of hypotension, but can restart
   if bp
s tolerate
   - Continue heparin gtt for now
   .
   # Presumed septic shock & diffuse lymphadenopathy: WBC still trending
   down, today 10.4.  Thought to be [**1-10**] presumed infection and cardiogenic
   (acute MR, afib with RVR) insult.  Off pressors since [**12-16**]. CT scan
   demonstrated diffuse lymphadenopathy & pulmonary nodules.  Etiology may
   be infection, but aside from HSV positive lip swab, extensive
   infectious work-up has been negative to date.  ID felt presentation was
   unlikely to be infectious, but has improved on Abx. HIV not tested as
   consent could not be obtained.  Heme/Onc did not feel presentation was
   likely to represent lymphoma.
   - Meropenem 500mg TID, day 14/14,  Doxycycline 100mg q12H, day [**11-21**],
   Acyclovir 400mg TID, day [**6-17**]
   - continue to trend CBC
   .
   # DECONDITIONING: Patient has been in the hospital for 16 days,
   intubated from [**Date range (1) 10393**].
   - PT/OT
   - encourage regular limb movement in bed
   - s/s re-eval tomorrow
   - continue TF to gain nutrition and strength back
   .
   # ? Right LE DVT: Patient was found to have  a possible old DVT in the
   right posterior tibial veins (normal compression, but no appearance of
   flow) on LENI
s performed on [**12-8**].
   - continue heparin gtt (also for Afib)
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has unknown anatomy as she has never had a prior
   cardiac catherizations, but MI is unlikely given lack of any EKG
   changes and negative troponins.
   - continue ASA 81mg daily
   .
   # Anemia: Normocytic, normochromic with normal RDW. Fe studies c/w ACD
   s/p 2u pRBC
s.  B12 and folate normal.  Hct stable.
   - Trend HCT daily
   .
   # Glaucoma:
   - Continue home eye drops
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH 3.3
   - Continue home Levothyroxine
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2129-12-21**] 01:14 AM 30 mL/hour

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and a recent admission to the hospital for heart failure and new atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She is currently in the ICU and has been improving from a respiratory standpoint, but is still requiring pressors and has a marked leukocytosis, which is concerning for septic shock.

The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple potential complications, including:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient is improving from a respiratory standpoint, but still requires oxygen therapy and has a mix of respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis, which may be due to hypoventilation and overdiuresis.
2. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has a high bicarbonate level and a low chloride level, which may be due to contraction alkalosis caused by overdiuresis. The patient's serum sodium level is also elevated, which may be due to overdiuresis and contraction alkalosis.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's serum sodium level is elevated, which may be due to overdiuresis and contraction alkalosis. The patient's free water deficit is calculated to be 2.9L, which may require further management.
4. Fluid overload: The patient has anasarca and continues to diurese well on IV Lasix. The patient's CVP is mildly elevated, which may require further management.
5. Pump/severe MR: The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and has a known mitral regurgitation tear at the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve. The patient's TTE shows normal EF, but the jet of MR is better appreciated on repeat TTE.
6. Rhythm: The patient goes in and out of atrial fibrillation, which may be due to fluid shifts and MR. The patient's TSH level is normal.
7. Presumed septic shock and diffuse lymphadenopathy: The patient has a presumed septic shock and diffuse lymphadenopathy, which may be due to an infection or cardiogenic insult. The patient's WBC count is trending down, and the patient has received antibiotics and antiviral therapy.
8. Deconditioning: The patient has been in the hospital for 16 days and has been intubated for several days, which may have contributed to her deconditioning.
9. Right LE DVT: The patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins, which may require further management.
10. Coronaries: The patient has unknown anatomy, but MI is unlikely given lack of EKG changes and negative troponins.
11. Anemia: The patient has normocytic, normochromic anemia with normal RDW, which may require further management.
12. Glaucoma: The patient has glaucoma, which may require further management.
13. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which may require further management.

The patient's current medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) 120mg IV x 1
* Meropenem 500mg TID
* Doxycycline 100mg q12H
* Acyclovir 400mg TID
* Amiodarone 200mg daily
* Heparin gtt
* Aspirin 81mg daily
* Levothyroxine
* Nutren 2.0 (Full) 30 mL/hour

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continue IV Lasix
* Continue meropenem, doxycycline, and acyclovir
* Continue amiodarone
* Continue heparin gtt
* Continue aspirin
* Continue Levothyroxine
* Continue Nutren 2.0 (Full)
* Monitor electrolytes and renal function
* Monitor WBC count
* Monitor CVP and MAP
* Continue daily CXR
* Continue TF
* Continue to discuss surgical option with patient

The patient's family meeting has been held, and the patient has decided not to undergo surgery at this time. The patient's daughter is aware of the patient's condition and has been informed of the patient's decision.

   83 y.o woman with chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history of
   generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for heart failure and new
   afib with RVR. She is improving after intubation requiring pressors and
   a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive
   cultures and a CT demonstrating diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary
   nodules.  Patient was extubated on [**12-17**], doing better from respiratory
   stand point, but likely need MVR for full recovery.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: ABG reveals a mix picture of respiratory
   acidosis and metabolic alkalosis, likely from hypoventilation and
   overdiuresis/contraction alkalosis.  RR remains in mid 20
s to upper
   30
s on 3L O2 by NC with adequate oxygenation all day yesterday.
   Patient received Lasix 120mg IV x 1 yesterday with resulting net
   negative 780cc.  Patient is improving from respiratory stand point, CXR
   improbing as well.  However, it is unclear how well she can get without
   MVR surgery.
   - f/u Csurg recs
   - keep HOB elevated
   - follow ABGs and respiratory status
   - continue standing Atrovent nebs
   - Complete Abx (Meropenem, Doxy, Acyclovir) regimen, finishing up
   meropenem today
   - continue TF
   .
   # METABOLIC ALKALOSIS:  This is most likely contraction alkalosis due
   to overdiuresis.  BUN/Cr ratio is way above 20. No vomiting and loss of
   hydrogen ions from GI system.  No insulin or hypokalemia leading to
   alkalosis either.
   - get urine Cl to see if the metabolic alkalosis is chloride-responsive
   (if Ucl <10, responsive, if >20, not responsive)
   - slow down on diuresis given likely contraction alkalosis
   - I/O goal of -500cc-1L
   - pm lytes
   .
   # HYPERNATREMIA:  Na climbing to 149 today.  Also likely due to
   overdiuresis. Free water deficit is calculated to be 2.9L.
   - continue free water flushes 200cc q6h
   - slow down on diuresis given likely contraction alkalosis
   - I/O goal of -500cc-1L
   - pm lytes
   .
   #. Fluid overload: Anasarca [**1-10**] fluid imbalance (multifactorial:
   hypoalbuminemia/chronic sCHF/
leaky capillary syndrome
), continues to
   improve. Patient continues to diurese well on IV Lasix.  Also with
   mildly elevated serum Na and HCO3 that may represent a contraction
   alkalosis.
   -  Goal diuresis is -0.5-1.0L today. Will exercise caution to maintain
   CVP ~ 10 & regulate electrolytes today.
   -  Closely monitor electrolytes and renal function [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Daily CXR
   -  CVP goal >10
   -  MAP goal is 60-65
   .
   # PUMP/SEVERE MR: History of chronic systolic heart failure, and
   patient
s initial sx were consistent with failure (SOB, orthopnea,
   edema), but TTE on admission showed normal EF (>60%). Patient also with
   known MR [**First Name (Titles) 43**] [**Last Name (Titles) 10178**] tear at posterior leaflet of mitral valve, likely
   contributing to worsening MR which causes overestimation of EF. Repeat
   TTE on [**12-16**] was unchanged from prior, but jet of MR was
better
   appreciated
 per interpretation.
   - need to get OSH dental records
   - TTE today per verbal Csurg recs
   - F/U additional Csurg recs
   .
   # Presumed septic shock & diffuse lymphadenopathy: WBC still trending
   down, today 10.4.  Thought to be [**1-10**] presumed infection and cardiogenic
   (acute MR, afib with RVR) insult.  Off pressors since [**12-16**]. CT scan
   demonstrated diffuse lymphadenopathy & pulmonary nodules.  Etiology may

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has a mix of respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis, likely due to hypoventilation and overdiuresis/contraction alkalosis. She is improving from a respiratory standpoint, with a CXR showing improvement.
* Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has a contraction alkalosis due to overdiuresis, with a BUN/Cr ratio above 20. The goal is to slow down diuresis and monitor electrolytes.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has a sodium level of 149, likely due to overdiuresis. A free water deficit of 2.9L is calculated, and the goal is to continue free water flushes and slow down diuresis.
* Fluid Overload: The patient has anasarca fluid imbalance, likely due to hypoalbuminemia, chronic systolic heart failure, and a leaky capillary syndrome. The goal is to diurese 0.5-1.0L today and maintain a CVP of 10.
* Pump/Severe MR: The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and mitral regurgitation (MR), which is likely contributing to her worsening condition. A repeat TTE is recommended.
* Presumed Septic Shock & Diffuse Lymphadenopathy: The patient has a presumed infection, likely due to HSV, and cardiogenic insult. She has been off pressors since 12-16 and is being treated with antibiotics.
* Rhythm: The patient goes in and out of atrial fibrillation (Afib), likely due to fluid shifts and MR. Amiodarone is being continued.
* Right LE DVT: The patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins, which is being monitored with heparin.
* Coronaries: The patient has unknown coronary anatomy, but MI is unlikely given the lack of EKG changes and negative troponins.
* Anemia: The patient has normocytic, normochromic anemia with normal RDW and stable Hct.
* Glaucoma: The patient has glaucoma and is being treated with home eye drops.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism and is being treated with home Levothyroxine.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's heart failure may worsen, leading to cardiogenic shock.
* Infection: The patient's presumed septic shock may progress, leading to sepsis or septic shock.
* Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's metabolic alkalosis and hypernatremia may worsen, leading to electrolyte imbalances.
* Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen, leading to pulmonary edema or cardiac failure.
* DVT: The patient's possible old DVT may progress, leading to DVT or pulmonary embolism.

Based on the patient's current status and potential complications, it is recommended to continue monitoring her respiratory, cardiac, and metabolic status closely, and to adjust treatment as needed to prevent or manage potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Respiratory Status:** The patient is improving from a respiratory standpoint, but still requires oxygen therapy and has a mix of respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis.

**Metabolic Alkalosis:** The patient has a contraction alkalosis due to overdiuresis, which is likely caused by the Lasix treatment. The BUN/Cr ratio is elevated, and the patient's creatinine levels are stable despite aggressive diuresis.

**Hypernatremia:** The patient's sodium levels are increasing, likely due to overdiuresis. The free water deficit is calculated to be 2.9L.

**Fluid Overload:** The patient has anasarca (fluid imbalance) due to hypoalbuminemia, chronic systolic heart failure, and leaky capillary syndrome.

**Pump/Severe MR:** The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and known mitral regurgitation (MR), which is likely contributing to her worsening condition.

**Rhythm:** The patient's heart rhythm is irregular and is likely due to fluid shifts and MR.

**Presumed Septic Shock:** The patient has a presumed septic shock and diffuse lymphadenopathy, which is being treated with antibiotics. The etiology is unclear, but the patient's condition has improved with antibiotic treatment.

**Deconditioning:** The patient has been in the hospital for 16 days and is at risk for deconditioning.

**Right LE DVT:** The patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins.

**Coronaries:** The patient has unknown coronary anatomy, but MI is unlikely given the lack of EKG changes and negative troponins.

**Anemia:** The patient has normocytic, normochromic anemia with normal RDW and stable Hct.

**Glaucoma:** The patient has glaucoma and is receiving home eye drops.

**Hypothyroidism:** The patient has hypothyroidism and is receiving home Levothyroxine.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she still requires oxygen therapy and may be at risk for respiratory failure if her condition worsens.
2. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's contraction alkalosis may lead to complications such as seizures, muscle weakness, and cardiac arrhythmias if not managed properly.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are increasing, which may lead to complications such as seizures, muscle weakness, and cardiac arrhythmias if not managed properly.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid imbalance may lead to complications such as pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, and electrolyte imbalances if not managed properly.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's presumed septic shock and diffuse lymphadenopathy may be due to pneumonia, which is a potential complication.
6. DVT: The patient's possible old DVT may lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism if not managed properly.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may lead to complications such as fatigue, weakness, and decreased immune function if not managed properly.
8. Glaucoma: The patient's glaucoma may lead to complications such as vision loss if not managed properly.
9. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may lead to complications such as fatigue, weight gain, and decreased cognitive function if not managed properly.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
2. Manage the patient's metabolic alkalosis and hypernatremia with fluids and electrolyte replacement as necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's fluid overload with diuretics and fluid restriction as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's presumed septic shock and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's DVT and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with iron supplements and blood transfusions as necessary.
7. Continue to manage the patient's glaucoma with home eye drops and follow-up appointments as necessary.
8. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism with home Levothyroxine and follow-up appointments as necessary.
9. Discuss the patient's surgical options with her and her family and obtain informed consent for any further procedures.

   83 y.o woman with chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history of
   generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for heart failure and new
   afib with RVR. She is improving after intubation requiring pressors and
   a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive
   cultures and a CT demonstrating diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary
   nodules.  Patient was extubated on [**12-17**], doing better from respiratory
   stand point, but likely need MVR for full recovery.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Patient is improving from respiratory stand
   point, CXR improving as well.  RR remains in mid 20
s to upper 30
s on
   3-4L O2 by NC with adequate oxygen saturation. Patient received Lasix
   bolus (80mg) plus gtt at 2.5mg/hr with good UOP.  However, Lasix gtt
   was held since yesterday evening due to hypotension in the setting of
   getting 50mg trazodone.  ABG reveals metabolic alkalosis, likely
   contraction alkalosis.  Although pt is improving from the respiratory
   stand point, it is unclear how well she can get without MVR surgery.
   - restart lasix gtt today with bolus (80mg), I/O goal of -500cc
   - keep HOB elevated
   - continue standing Atrovent nebs
   - Complete Abx (Doxy, Acyclovir) regimen, meropenem d/c
d today
   - continue TF (boost glucose control)
   - per S/S, can have pleasure feeds in moisture purees and nectar
   thickened liquids, but main source of nutrition continues to be TF
   - follow ABGs and respiratory status
   - f/u Csurg recs, if any
   .
   # INSOMNIA: Patient received 50mg trazodone last night at 7pm, was up
   most of the time until 3am.  Daughter and patient herself were very
   concerned about the fact that she was not getting enough sleep.
   - consult geriatrics regarding the best sleeping med for an 83 year
   old, consider remeron, atypical antipsychotics or lower dose trazodone
   - if giving trazodone, no more than 37.5mg
   .
   # HYPOTENSION:  Patient was hypotensive after trazodone was given.  The
   most likely etiology was medication effect. 1-10% patients develop
   hypotension after receiving trazodone.  Other etiologies were
   unlikely.  Patient has been on heparin, so PE is unlikely.  ACS
   unlikely as patient asymptomatic, and patient has no history of ACS.
   Her coronary artery anatomy is unknown, but her plaque burden in
   carotid arteries is close to 0.  Pneumothorax was not seen in CXR after
   PICC was placed, and she had bilateral breath sounds, and was satting
   well.
   - If giving trazodone, no more than 37.5mg
   - look for another sleeping medication as above
   .
   # METABOLIC ALKALOSIS:  This is most likely due to Lasix diuresis and
   contraction alkalosis.  BUN/Cr ratio is way above 20. Curiously,
   creatinine has been flat and even down-trending despite aggressive
   diuresis and contraction alkalosis.  FeUrea: 29.7, Urine osm 563, serum
   osm: 321, these numbers indicate patient is not very dry.  Urine Na
   20.  Urine Cl: 24 (>20), indicating less Cl-responsiveness.  No other
   etiologies can explain this metabolic alkalosi, patient has no vomiting
   and loss of hydrogen ions from GI system, and no insulin or hypokalemia
   leading to alkalosis either.
   - restart lasix gtt today with bolus (80mg), I/O goal of -500cc
   - pm lytes
   .
   # HYPERNATREMIA:  Na stable.  TF was changed to less concentrated boost
   glucose control.  Hypernatremia is likely due to diuresis. Free water
   deficit is calculated to be 2.9L.
   - continue free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - restart lasix gtt today with bolus (80mg), I/O goal of -500cc
   - pm lytes
   .
   #. FLUID OVERLOAD: Anasarca [**1-10**] fluid imbalance (multifactorial:
   hypoalbuminemia/chronic sCHF/
leaky capillary syndrome
), continues to
   improve. Patient continues to diurese well on IV Lasix gtt.  Also with
   mildly elevated serum Na and HCO3 that may represent a Lasix effect and
   contraction alkalosis.
   -  Goal diuresis is -0.5L today. Will exercise caution to maintain CVP

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with chronic systolic heart failure, recently admitted to the ICU for heart failure and new atrial fibrillation with right ventricular overload. She has been improving from a respiratory standpoint, but remains at risk for septic shock despite negative cultures and a CT scan showing diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary nodules. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, insomnia, and metabolic alkalosis, and is at risk for fluid overload, anemia, and leukocytosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be related to medication effects, including trazodone, and may require further evaluation and management.
2. Insomnia: The patient's insomnia may be related to her underlying medical condition and may require further evaluation and management, including consultation with geriatrics.
3. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis may be related to Lasix diuresis and contraction alkalosis, and may require further evaluation and management, including electrolyte monitoring and fluid management.
4. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid overload may be related to her underlying medical condition and may require further evaluation and management, including diuretic therapy and fluid restriction.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to her underlying medical condition and may require further evaluation and management, including transfusion therapy and iron supplementation.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be related to her underlying medical condition and may require further evaluation and management, including antibiotic therapy and infectious disease consultation.
7. Right Lower Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's possible old DVT may require further evaluation and management, including anticoagulation therapy and compression stockings.
8. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may require further evaluation and management, including anticoagulation therapy and rate control medication.
9. Pulmonary Nodules: The patient's pulmonary nodules may require further evaluation and management, including imaging studies and biopsy.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing evaluation and management. The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains at risk for septic shock and fluid overload. The patient's hypotension and insomnia require further evaluation and management, and the patient's metabolic alkalosis and anemia require ongoing monitoring and management. The patient's leukocytosis requires further evaluation and management, including antibiotic therapy and infectious disease consultation. The patient's possible old DVT requires further evaluation and management, including anticoagulation therapy and compression stockings. The patient's atrial fibrillation requires further evaluation and management, including anticoagulation therapy and rate control medication. The patient's pulmonary nodules require further evaluation and management, including imaging studies and biopsy.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y.o woman with chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history of
   generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for heart failure and new
   afib with RVR. She is improving after intubation requiring pressors and
   a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive
   cultures and a CT demonstrating diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary
   nodules.  Patient was extubated on [**12-17**], doing better from respiratory
   stand point, but likely need MVR for full recovery.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Patient is improving from respiratory stand
   point, CXR improving as well.  RR remains in mid 20
s to upper 30
s on
   3-4L O2 by NC with adequate oxygen saturation. Patient received Lasix
   bolus (80mg) plus gtt at 2.5mg/hr with good UOP.  However, Lasix gtt
   was held since yesterday evening due to hypotension in the setting of
   getting 50mg trazodone.  ABG reveals metabolic alkalosis, likely
   contraction alkalosis.  Although pt is improving from the respiratory
   stand point, it is unclear how well she can get without MVR surgery.
   - restart lasix gtt today with bolus (80mg), I/O goal of -500cc
   - keep HOB elevated
   - continue standing Atrovent nebs
   - Complete Abx (Doxy, Acyclovir) regimen, meropenem d/c
d today
   - continue TF (boost glucose control)
   - per S/S, can have pleasure feeds in moisture purees and nectar
   thickened liquids, but main source of nutrition continues to be TF
   - follow ABGs and respiratory status
   - f/u Csurg recs, if any
   .
   # INSOMNIA: Patient received 50mg trazodone last night at 7pm, was up
   most of the time until 3am.  Daughter and patient herself were very
   concerned about the fact that she was not getting enough sleep.
   - consult geriatrics regarding the best sleeping med for an 83 year
   old, consider remeron, atypical antipsychotics or lower dose trazodone
   - if giving trazodone, no more than 37.5mg
   .
   # HYPOTENSION:  Patient was hypotensive after trazodone was given.  The
   most likely etiology was medication effect. 1-10% patients develop
   hypotension after receiving trazodone.  Other etiologies were
   unlikely.  Patient has been on heparin, so PE is unlikely.  ACS
   unlikely as patient asymptomatic, and patient has no history of ACS.
   Her coronary artery anatomy is unknown, but her plaque burden in
   carotid arteries is close to 0.  Pneumothorax was not seen in CXR after
   PICC was placed, and she had bilateral breath sounds, and was satting
   well.
   - If giving trazodone, no more than 37.5mg
   - look for another sleeping medication as above
   .
   # METABOLIC ALKALOSIS:  This is most likely due to Lasix diuresis and
   contraction alkalosis.  BUN/Cr ratio is way above 20. Curiously,
   creatinine has been flat and even down-trending despite aggressive
   diuresis and contraction alkalosis.  FeUrea: 29.7, Urine osm 563, serum
   osm: 321, these numbers indicate patient is not very dry.  Urine Na
   20.  Urine Cl: 24 (>20), indicating less Cl-responsiveness.  No other
   etiologies can explain this metabolic alkalosi, patient has no vomiting
   and loss of hydrogen ions from GI system, and no insulin or hypokalemia
   leading to alkalosis either.
   - restart lasix gtt today with bolus (80mg), I/O goal of -500cc
   - pm lytes
   .
   # HYPERNATREMIA:  Na stable.  TF was changed to less concentrated boost
   glucose control.  Hypernatremia is likely due to diuresis. Free water
   deficit is calculated to be 2.9L.
   - continue free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - restart lasix gtt today with bolus (80mg), I/O goal of -500cc
   - pm lytes
   .
   #. FLUID OVERLOAD: Anasarca [**1-10**] fluid imbalance (multifactorial:
   hypoalbuminemia/chronic sCHF/
leaky capillary syndrome
), continues to
   improve. Patient continues to diurese well on IV Lasix gtt.  Also with
   mildly elevated serum Na and HCO3 that may represent a Lasix effect and
   contraction alkalosis.
   -  Goal diuresis is -0.5L today. Will exercise caution to maintain CVP
   ~ 10 & regulate electrolytes today.
   -  Closely monitor electrolytes and renal function [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Daily CXR
   -  CVP goal >10
   -  MAP goal is 60-65
   .
   # DECONDITIONING: Patient has been in the hospital for 17 days,
   intubated from [**Date range (1) 10393**].
   - continue PT/OT
   - encourage regular limb movement in bed
   - continue TF to gain nutrition and strength back
   .
   # Anemia/Hct drop: Hct dropped to 27.9 to 25.5 over 24 hours.  Part of
   this is due to hemodilution given the 1L NS she received overnight due
   to hypotension.  Normocytic, normochromic with normal RDW. Fe studies
   c/w ACD s/p 2u pRBC
s during the earlier part of this hospital stay.
   B12 and folate normal.
   - guaiac all stools
   - Trend HCT daily
   .
   # LEUKOCYTOSIS: WBC bumped up from a nadir of 10.4 yesterday ([**2129-12-21**])
   to 12.5 today.  Patient is afebrile, no sign of localized infection.
   Her peak WBC during this admission was 49.1.  This was thought to be
   [**1-10**] presumed infection and cardiogenic (acute MR, afib with RVR)
   insult.  Off pressors since [**12-16**]. CT scan demonstrated diffuse
   lymphadenopathy & pulmonary nodules.  Etiology may be infection, but
   aside from HSV positive lip swab, extensive infectious work-up has been
   negative to date.  ID felt presentation was unlikely to be infectious,
   but has improved on Abx. HIV not tested as consent could not be
   obtained.  Heme/Onc did not feel presentation was likely to represent
   lymphoma.
   - meropenem d/c
d today
   - Doxycycline 100mg q12H, day 13/14, Acyclovir 400mg TID, day [**7-18**]
   - if fever, would culture and get CXR
   - continue to trend CBC
   .
   # PUMP/SEVERE MR: History of chronic systolic heart failure, and
   patient
s initial sx were consistent with failure (SOB, orthopnea,
   edema), but TTE on admission showed normal EF (>60%). Patient also with
   known MR [**First Name (Titles) 43**] [**Last Name (Titles) 10178**] tear at posterior leaflet of mitral valve, likely
   contributing to worsening MR which causes overestimation of EF. Repeat
   TTE on [**12-16**] was unchanged from prior, but jet of MR was
better
   appreciated
 per interpretation.  Per Csurgery, no more pre-op testing
   is necessary until pt makes the decision to go for surgery.  Currently,
   patient is still leaning toward no surgery, but this may change as
   patient feels better.
   - continue to discuss surgical option with patient
   - F/U Csurg recs, if any
   - need to get OSH dental records if pt decides to go for MVR
   - carotid US showed 0% stenosis
   .
   # RHYTHM: Pt goes in and out of Afib.  Fluid shifts may be responsible,
   but MR is the main contributing factor although LA is not significantly
   dilated given prominent regurgitant jet.  TSH normal.
   - change amiodarone from 200mg [**Hospital1 **] to 200mg daily
   - Holding nodal agents in the setting of hypotension, but can restart
   if bp
s tolerate
   - Continue heparin gtt for now
   .
   # ? Right LE DVT: Patient was found to have a possible old DVT in the
   right posterior tibial veins (normal compression, but no appearance of
   flow) on LENI
s performed on [**12-8**].
   - continue heparin gtt (also for Afib)
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has unknown anatomy as she has never had a prior
   cardiac catherizations, but MI is unlikely given lack of any EKG
   changes and negative troponins.
   - continue ASA 81mg daily
   .
   # Glaucoma:
   - Continue home eye drops
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH 3.3
   - Continue home Levothyroxine
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Boost Glucose Control (Full) - [**2129-12-22**] 04:00 AM 50 mL/hour

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

1. The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, who was recently admitted to the ICU for heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR).
2. The patient has been improving from a respiratory standpoint, with decreasing oxygen requirements and improving CXR findings. However, she still requires 3-4L of oxygen via nasal cannula.
3. The patient's metabolic alkalosis is likely due to Lasix diuresis and contraction alkalosis, and her hypernatremia is likely due to diuresis.
4. The patient has a fluid overload, which is improving with diuresis, and her electrolytes are being closely monitored.
5. The patient has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 25.5 g/dL, and her WBC count has been increasing, likely due to a presumed infection or cardiogenic insult.
6. The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and has undergone cardiac catheterization, which showed normal EF (>60%). However, she has a known mitral regurgitation (MR) tear at the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, which may be contributing to her worsening MR.
7. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which may be due to medication effect, and has been receiving pressors to maintain her blood pressure.
8. The patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins, which is being treated with heparin.
9. The patient has a history of glaucoma and hypothyroidism, which are being managed with home eye drops and Levothyroxine, respectively.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she still requires significant oxygen therapy, and her respiratory function may deteriorate if she develops pneumonia or another respiratory infection.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's AFib with RVR may progress to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular tachycardia (AFib with RVT), which can lead to cardiac arrest or stroke. Her mitral regurgitation may worsen, leading to heart failure or cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's increasing WBC count and possible old DVT may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's metabolic alkalosis and hypernatremia may lead to electrolyte imbalances, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or seizures.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen, leading to pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, or renal failure.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased cognitive function.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to decreased organ perfusion, shock, or cardiac arrest.

Based on these potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust her oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiac status, including her AFib with RVR and mitral regurgitation.
3. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust her fluid and electrolyte therapy as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's WBC count and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusing her if her hemoglobin level falls below 20 g/dL.
6. Monitor the patient's hypotension and adjust her pressor therapy as needed.
7. Consider sending the patient to IR for PICC placement once she is stable enough to do so.
8. Continue to discuss the patient's surgical options with her and her daughter, including the possibility of mitral valve repair or replacement.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y.o woman with chronic systolic CHF with 2 week history of
   generalized weakness and shortness of breath, recently admitted to
   [**Hospital3 **] now transferred here to [**Hospital1 1**] for heart failure and new
   afib with RVR. She is improving after intubation requiring pressors and
   a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive
   cultures and a CT demonstrating diffuse lymphadenopathy with pulmonary
   nodules.  Patient was extubated on [**12-17**], doing better from respiratory
   stand point, but likely need MVR for full recovery.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Patient is improving from respiratory stand
   point, CXR improving as well.  RR remains in mid 20
s to upper 30
s on
   3-4L O2 by NC with adequate oxygen saturation. Patient received Lasix
   bolus (80mg) plus gtt at 2.5mg/hr with good UOP.  However, Lasix gtt
   was held since yesterday evening due to hypotension in the setting of
   getting 50mg trazodone.  ABG reveals metabolic alkalosis, likely
   contraction alkalosis.  Although pt is improving from the respiratory
   stand point, it is unclear how well she can get without MVR surgery.
   - restart lasix gtt today at 10mg/hr.  Assess at noon time today, will
   give Lasix bolus 80mg if UOP <80cc/hr.  Goal I/O -500cc today.
   - keep HOB elevated
   - continue standing Atrovent nebs
   - Complete Abx (Doxy, Acyclovir) regimen, meropenem d/c
d today
   - continue TF (boost glucose control)
   - per S/S, can have pleasure feeds in moisture purees and nectar
   thickened liquids, but main source of nutrition continues to be TF
   - follow ABGs and respiratory status
   - f/u Csurg recs, if any
   .
   # INSOMNIA: Patient received 50mg trazodone last night at 7pm, was up
   most of the time until 3am.  Daughter and patient herself were very
   concerned about the fact that she was not getting enough sleep.  Other
   meds that have been considered include remeron, Ativan, ambien,
   atypical antipsychotics or lower dose trazodone
   - give remeron 15mg and Ativan prn for sleep tonight.
   .
   # HYPOTENSION:  Patient was hypotensive after trazodone was given.  The
   most likely etiology was medication effect. 1-10% patients develop
   hypotension after receiving trazodone.  Other etiologies were
   unlikely.  Patient has been on heparin, so PE is unlikely.  ACS
   unlikely as patient asymptomatic, and patient has no history of ACS.
   Her coronary artery anatomy is unknown, but her plaque burden in
   carotid arteries is close to 0.  Pneumothorax was not seen in CXR after
   PICC was placed, and she had bilateral breath sounds, and was satting
   well.
   - give remeron and low dose ativan for sleep
   .
   # METABOLIC ALKALOSIS:  This is most likely due to Lasix diuresis and
   contraction alkalosis.  BUN/Cr ratio is way above 20. Curiously,
   creatinine has been flat and even down-trending despite aggressive
   diuresis and contraction alkalosis.  FeUrea: 29.7, Urine osm 563, serum
   osm: 321, urine Na 20,  these numbers indicate patient is not terribly
   dry.  Urine Cl: 24 (>20), indicating less Cl-responsiveness.  No other
   etiologies can explain this metabolic alkalosi, patient has no vomiting
   and loss of hydrogen ions from GI system, and no insulin or hypokalemia
   leading to alkalosis either.
   - restart lasix gtt today at 10mg/hr.  Assess at noon time today, will
   give Lasix bolus 80mg if UOP <80cc/hr.  goal I/O -500cc today.
   - pm lytes
   .
   # HYPERNATREMIA:  Na stable.  TF was changed to less concentrated boost
   glucose control.  Hypernatremia is likely due to diuresis. Free water
   deficit continues to be 2.9L.
   - continue free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - restart lasix gtt today at 10mg/hr.  Assess at noon time today, will
   give Lasix bolus 80mg if UOP <80cc/hr.  Goal I/O -500cc today.
   - pm lytes
   .
   #. FLUID OVERLOAD: Anasarca [**1-10**] fluid imbalance (multifactorial:
   hypoalbuminemia/chronic sCHF/
leaky capillary syndrome
), continues to
   improve. Patient continues to diurese well on IV Lasix gtt.  Also with
   mildly elevated serum Na and HCO3 that may represent a Lasix effect and
   contraction alkalosis.
   -  restart lasix gtt today at 10mg/hr.  Assess at noon time today, will
   give Lasix bolus 80mg if UOP <80cc/hr.  goal I/O -500cc today.
   -  Closely monitor electrolytes and renal function [**Hospital1 **]
   -  Daily CXR
   -  CVP goal >10
   -  MAP goal is 60-65
   .
   # DECONDITIONING: Patient has been in the hospital for 17 days,
   intubated from [**Date range (1) 10393**].
   - continue PT/OT
   - encourage regular limb movement in bed
   - continue TF to gain nutrition and strength back
   .
   # Anemia/Hct drop: Hct dropped to 27.9 to 25.5 over 24 hours.  Part of
   this is due to hemodilution given the 1L NS she received overnight due
   to hypotension.  Also PICC line was placed yesterday which could have
   caused some blood loss.   Normocytic, normochromic with normal RDW. Fe
   studies c/w ACD s/p 2u pRBC
s during the earlier part of this hospital
   stay.  B12 and folate normal.
   - guaiac all stools
   - send for c.diff
   - get pm hct, goal hct 21
   .
   # LEUKOCYTOSIS: WBC bumped up from a nadir of 10.4 yesterday ([**2129-12-21**])
   to 12.5 today.  Patient is afebrile, no sign of localized infection.
   Her peak WBC during this admission was 49.1.  This was thought to be
   [**1-10**] presumed infection and cardiogenic (acute MR, afib with RVR)
   insult.  Off pressors since [**12-16**]. CT scan demonstrated diffuse
   lymphadenopathy & pulmonary nodules.  Etiology may be infection, but
   aside from HSV positive lip swab, extensive infectious work-up has been
   negative to date.  ID felt presentation was unlikely to be infectious,
   but has improved on Abx. HIV not tested as consent could not be
   obtained.  Heme/Onc did not feel presentation was likely to represent
   lymphoma.
   - meropenem d/c
d today
   - send c.diff
   - Doxycycline 100mg q12H, day 13/14, Acyclovir 400mg TID, day [**7-18**]
   - if fever, would culture and get CXR.  Would start vanc and flagyl,
   pull out CVL if febrile.
   - continue to trend CBC
   .
   # PUMP/SEVERE MR: History of chronic systolic heart failure, and
   patient
s initial sx were consistent with failure (SOB, orthopnea,
   edema), but TTE on admission showed normal EF (>60%). Patient also with
   known MR [**First Name (Titles) 43**] [**Last Name (Titles) 10178**] tear at posterior leaflet of mitral valve, likely
   contributing to worsening MR which causes overestimation of EF. Repeat
   TTE on [**12-16**] was unchanged from prior, but jet of MR was
better
   appreciated
 per interpretation.  Per Csurgery, no more pre-op testing
   is necessary until pt makes the decision to go for surgery.  Currently,
   patient does not want surgery currently, but this may change as patient
   feels better.
   - continue to discuss surgical option with patient when she feels
   better
   - F/U Csurg recs, if any
   - need to get OSH dental records if pt decides to go for MVR
   - carotid US showed 0% stenosis
   .
   # RHYTHM: Pt goes in and out of Afib.  Fluid shifts may be responsible,
   but MR is the main contributing factor although LA is not significantly
   dilated given prominent regurgitant jet.  TSH normal.
   - change amiodarone from 200mg [**Hospital1 **] to 200mg daily
   - Holding nodal agents in the setting of hypotension, but can restart
   if bp
s tolerate
   - Continue heparin gtt for now

   .
   # ? Right LE DVT: Patient was found to have a possible old DVT in the
   right posterior tibial veins (normal compression, but no appearance of

s performed on [**12-8**].
   - continue heparin gtt (also for Afib)
   - start coumadin 2.5mg daily
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient has unknown anatomy as she has never had a prior

   changes and negative troponins.
   - continue ASA 81mg daily

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient is improving from a respiratory standpoint, but still requires 3-4L O2 by nasal cannula to maintain oxygen saturation. She has a history of chronic systolic CHF and recently developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
2. Insomnia: The patient has been having difficulty sleeping, with a recent episode of insomnia after receiving trazodone. She has been prescribed remeron and ativan for sleep.
3. Hypotension: The patient experienced hypotension after receiving trazodone, which was likely due to medication effect. Her blood pressure has been stable since then.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has a metabolic alkalosis, likely due to Lasix diuresis and contraction alkalosis. Her serum bicarbonate level is elevated, and her urine pH is slightly alkaline.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient has a mild hypernatremia, likely due to diuresis. Her free water deficit is 2.9L.
6. Fluid Overload: The patient has anasarca (fluid overload) due to chronic systolic CHF, hypoalbuminemia, and leaky capillary syndrome.
7. Leukocytosis: The patient has a leukocytosis, which is likely due to a presumed infection and cardiogenic insult. Her white blood cell count has increased from a nadir of 10.4 to 12.5.
8. Anemia/Hct Drop: The patient's hemoglobin level has dropped from 27.9 to 25.5 over 24 hours, likely due to hemodilution and blood loss from the PICC line placement.
9. Pumps/Severe MR: The patient has a history of chronic systolic CHF and a known mitral valve tear, which is contributing to worsening mitral regurgitation.
10. Rhythm: The patient's rhythm is atrial fibrillation, which is likely due to fluid shifts and mitral regurgitation.
11. Right LE DVT: The patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins, which is being treated with heparin and coumadin.
12. Coronaries: The patient has unknown coronary anatomy, but MI is unlikely given the lack of EKG changes and negative troponins.
13. Glaucoma: The patient has glaucoma, which is being managed with home eye drops.
14. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which is being managed with home Levothyroxine.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress can worsen, leading to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation can worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and potential cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and presumed infection can lead to sepsis if not managed promptly.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's anasarca (fluid overload) can worsen, leading to further fluid overload and potential cardiac failure.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and hemoglobin drop can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding if not managed properly.
6. Pulmonary edema: The patient's fluid overload and anasarca can lead to pulmonary edema if not managed promptly.
7. Cardiac failure: The patient's chronic systolic CHF can worsen, leading to cardiac failure if not managed properly.

Based on these conditions and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with antiarrhythmic medications and close monitoring.
3. Continue to treat the patient's presumed infection with antibiotics and close monitoring.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust diuretic therapy as needed to prevent fluid overload.
5. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust therapy as needed to prevent bleeding.
6. Continue to manage the patient's glaucoma with home eye drops.
7. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism with home Levothyroxine.
8. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiac therapy and management.
9. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist to optimize the patient's respiratory therapy and management.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, who was recently admitted to the ICU for heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). She was intubated and required pressors, but is now improving and has been extubated. The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure, and her initial symptoms were consistent with failure (shortness of breath, orthopnea, edema). However, her echocardiogram showed normal ejection fraction (>60%). The patient also has known mitral regurgitation (MR) due to a tear in the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, which may be contributing to her worsening MR.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: improving, but still requires 3-4L of oxygen by nasal cannula
* Cardiovascular: AFib with RVR, mitral regurgitation, and possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins
* Renal: diuresis and contraction alkalosis, with a goal of I/O -500cc today
* Electrolytes: metabolic alkalosis, with a BUN/Cr ratio above 20
* Hematology: anemia, with a Hct drop from 27.9 to 25.5 over 24 hours
* Infections: leukocytosis, with a WBC count of 12.5, but no signs of localized infection
* Medications: Lasix, heparin, meropenem, doxycycline, acyclovir, and other medications as listed

Potential medical complications:

* Hypotension: the patient's blood pressure dropped to 70s after receiving trazodone, and she was given 250cc boluses of IV fluids overnight
* Metabolic alkalosis: the patient has a metabolic alkalosis, likely due to Lasix diuresis and contraction alkalosis
* Hypernatremia: the patient's sodium levels are stable, but her free water deficit is 2.9L
* Fluid overload: the patient has anasarca, a condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the tissues, which is improving with diuresis
* Deconditioning: the patient has been in the hospital for 17 days and has been intubated, which may lead to deconditioning
* Anemia/Hct drop: the patient's Hct dropped from 27.9 to 25.5 over 24 hours, which may be due to hemodilution and blood loss from the PICC line placement
* Leukocytosis: the patient's WBC count is elevated, but she is afebrile and has no signs of localized infection
* PUMP/Severe MR: the patient has mitral regurgitation, which may lead to cardiac failure and other complications
* Rhythm: the patient goes in and out of AFib, which may be due to fluid shifts and MR
* Right LE DVT: the patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins, which may be contributing to her symptoms

Recommendations:

* Restart Lasix gtt at 10mg/hr and assess at noon time today, with a goal of I/O -500cc today
* Give remeron 15mg and Ativan prn for sleep tonight
* Continue free water flushes 250cc q6h to manage hypernatremia
* Monitor electrolytes and renal function closely
* Discuss surgical option with patient when she feels better
* Continue to trend CBC and consider sending c.diff
* Continue heparin gtt and coumadin 2.5mg daily for DVT prophylaxis
* Start coumadin 2.5mg daily for Afib prophylaxis
* Continue ASA 81mg daily for coronary artery disease prevention
* Continue home eye drops for glaucoma and home Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic heart failure (CHF) and atrial fibrillation (AF). She was admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, anasarca (fluid overload), and leukocytosis. She has been intubated and receiving pressors to support her blood pressure. Her respiratory status has improved, but she remains deconditioned and at risk for aspiration. She is also experiencing hypernatremia, metabolic alkalosis, and anemia of chronic inflammation. Her cardiac status is stable, but she is refusing mitral valve repair surgery.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory status remains precarious, and she is at risk for further decompensation. Close monitoring of her oxygen saturation and respiratory rate is essential.
2. Fluid Overload: The patient's anasarca is slowly improving, but she remains at risk for further fluid accumulation. Close monitoring of her fluid balance and electrolyte levels is essential.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is stable, but it is unclear whether it is related to an underlying infection or inflammation. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and potential complications.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis is stable, but it is essential to continue monitoring her electrolyte levels and adjusting her diuretic therapy as needed.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is stable, but it is essential to continue monitoring her electrolyte levels and adjusting her fluid therapy as needed.
6. Anemia of Chronic Inflammation: The patient's anemia of chronic inflammation is stable, but it is essential to continue monitoring her hemoglobin levels and adjusting her iron and folate supplementation as needed.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but she is at risk for further cardiac complications, including heart failure and arrhythmias.
8. Insomnia: The patient's insomnia is improving, but it is essential to continue monitoring her sleep patterns and adjusting her sedation therapy as needed.
9. Right Lower Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a possible old DVT in her right posterior tibial veins, which is being treated with heparin and Coumadin.
10. Glaucoma: The patient has glaucoma, which requires ongoing management with home eye drops.
11. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which requires ongoing management with home levothyroxine.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing close monitoring and management. The patient's respiratory status, fluid balance, electrolyte levels, and cardiac function need to be closely monitored. The patient's anemia of chronic inflammation, leukocytosis, and hypernatremia need to be further evaluated and managed. The patient's insomnia and glaucoma require ongoing management. The patient's DVT and hypothyroidism require ongoing management with anticoagulation therapy and thyroid hormone replacement, respectively.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of chronic systolic heart failure (EF >60%) and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). She has been in the hospital for 18 days and has been intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has been improving from a respiratory standpoint, but remains deconditioned and at risk for aspiration.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Fluid overload: The patient has anasarca, which is slowly improving with diuresis on IV Lasix gtt. However, she has hypernatremia and elevated HCO3 levels due to contraction alkalosis.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is stable at 12.7, and she is afebrile with no signs of localized infection.
3. Anemia of chronic inflammation: The patient's anemia is stable, and her blood counts are normal.
4. Cardiac: The patient's cardiac pump function is stable, but she remains in AFib. She has a history of possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins.
5. Insomnia: The patient is improving on Mirtazapine 15mg qHS without adverse side effects.
6. Glaucoma: The patient has a history of glaucoma and is taking home eye drops.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function is normal.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning off oxygen therapy as tolerated.
2. Elevating the head of bed to 30-45 degrees to reduce aspiration risk.
3. Encouraging out-of-bed activities, such as standing and walking.
4. Continuing diuresis with IV Lasix gtt to manage fluid overload.
5. Monitoring electrolytes and renal function closely.
6. Continuing anticoagulation therapy with Coumadin to prevent DVT and pulmonary embolism.
7. Re-evaluating the patient's cardiac status and considering further work-up for her leukocytosis.

The patient's disposition is pending a thorough evaluation of her respiratory status and decisions regarding placement.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a 2-week history of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, transferred to the ICU for heart failure and new-onset atrial fibrillation with right ventricular failure. She has been intubated and has required pressors and a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive cultures. The patient has been improving from a respiratory standpoint but remains deconditioned, making clearing her airway challenging and aspiration risk significant. She has been extubated and is tolerating Lasix gtt at 10mg/hr well, meeting fluid goals.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains deconditioned, making clearing her airway challenging and aspiration risk significant.
2. Fluid Overload: The patient has anasarca, a multifactorial fluid imbalance, and is slowly improving. She is diuresing on IV Lasix gtt, resulting in hypernatremia and elevated HCO3 from contraction alkalosis.
3. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has stable metabolic alkalosis, likely due to Lasix diuresis and contraction alkalosis.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient has stable hypernatremia, likely due to TF changed to less concentrated boost glucose control and free water flushes increased.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient has stable leukocytosis, from 12.5 to 12.7, with no sign of localized infection. C. diff sent on [**12-22**] for diarrhea was negative.
6. Anemia of Chronic Inflammation: The patient has stable anemia, normocytic, normochromic with normal RDW, and normal B12 and folate levels.
7. Cardiac: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation, likely contributing to pulmonary status, and is refusing MVR surgery. She is in atrial fibrillation and is on Amiodarone 200mg daily, Heparin gtt, and Coumadin 2.5mg daily.
8. Insomnia: The patient has improved on Mirtazapine 15mg qHS without adverse side effects aside from residual somnolence this AM, but patient easily rousable.
9. Right LE DVT: The patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins, which was detected on LENI performed on [**12-8**].
10. Glaucoma: The patient has glaucoma and is continuing home eye drops.
11. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism and is continuing home Levothyroxine.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains deconditioned, making clearing her airway challenging and aspiration risk significant. She is tolerating Lasix gtt at 10mg/hr well, meeting fluid goals. The patient has been extubated and is requiring oxygen therapy. She is also requiring pressors and has a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive cultures.

The patient's fluid overload is slowly improving, and she is diuresing on IV Lasix gtt, resulting in hypernatremia and elevated HCO3 from contraction alkalosis. Her metabolic alkalosis is stable, and her hypernatremia is stable.

The patient's leukocytosis is stable, and her anemia is stable. Her cardiac status is stable, with severe mitral regurgitation and atrial fibrillation. Her insomnia is improving on Mirtazapine 15mg qHS, and her right LE DVT is a possible old DVT.

The patient's glaucoma and hypothyroidism are stable, and she is continuing home eye drops and Levothyroxine, respectively.

The plan is to continue Lasix gtt at 10mg/hr, wean oxygen therapy as tolerated, and monitor electrolytes and renal function closely. The patient will also continue to receive pressors and antibiotics as needed. The patient's disposition is pending S&S eval and decisions regarding placement.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old woman admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation, AFib, and has been receiving various medications, including Lasix, Mirtaz, and Ativan, for insomnia. She has a history of hydrochlorothiazide allergy and has been taking antibiotics, including Acyclovir and Meropenem, which were discontinued. The patient has been experiencing gastrointestinal issues, including a positive guaiac stool test, which was later found to be negative for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff). She has also been experiencing fluid imbalance, with a total input of 3,055 mL and a total output of 3,410 mL, resulting in a negative fluid balance of -355 mL.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C (97.2°F), heart rate of 98 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 92/48 mmHg. Her respiratory status is also stable, with a SpO2 of 97% and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. The patient's neurological status is also stable, with an alert and oriented mental status and purposeful movement of all extremities.

The patient has several lab results, including a white blood cell count of 11.6, hemoglobin of 8.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 97,000. Her liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, are slightly elevated. Her renal function is also slightly impaired, with a creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid imbalance could lead to fluid overload, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiac status.
2. Infection: The patient's positive guaiac stool test and elevated white blood cell count could indicate an underlying infection, which could worsen her condition.
3. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is slightly low, which could increase her risk of bleeding, especially with the use of anticoagulant medications such as heparin and Coumadin.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is slightly elevated, which could indicate early signs of respiratory failure.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation could worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications.

Based on the patient's lab results and vital signs, it is recommended that she continue to receive close monitoring and medical attention to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 65-year-old woman admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation, and has been receiving treatment for 3 days. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 92/48 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 97% on nasal cannula.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure of 4 mmHg, and the patient is receiving heparin and furosemide infusions. The patient's fluid balance is positive, with a total input of 3,055 mL and a total output of 3,410 mL.

The patient's physical examination reveals a soft and non-tender abdomen, warm and well-perfused extremities, and 2+ edema in the lower extremities and right arm. The patient's skin examination shows blood-crusted lesions along the lower lip and vermilion border, with no active bleeding or erosions.

Laboratory results show the patient's white blood cell count is 11.6, hemoglobin is 8.8 g/dL, and platelet count is 643 K/uL. The patient's creatinine is 0.7 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen is 38 mEq/L. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's glucose level is 132 mg/dL, and her lactate level is 0.7 mmol/L. The patient's albumin level is 2.0 g/dL, and her liver enzymes are within normal limits.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Infection: The patient's positive guaiac stool test and negative C. difficile test may indicate a gastrointestinal infection. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate an inflammatory response.
2. Fluid overload: The patient's positive fluid balance and elevated central venous pressure may indicate fluid overload, which can lead to pulmonary edema and cardiac failure.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is elevated, which may indicate a bleeding risk.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's slightly elevated potassium level may indicate an electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
5. Wound infection: The patient's blood-crusted lesions along the lower lip and vermilion border may be at risk of infection, especially with the patient's compromised immune status.
6. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate level may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.

Based on the patient's condition, the ICU team should continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings. The team should also consider implementing measures to prevent and manage potential complications, such as infection, fluid overload, thrombocytopenia, electrolyte imbalance, wound infection, and sepsis.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y.o woman with chronic sCHF (EF >60%) with 2 week history of
   generalized weakness and shortness of breath, transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   heart failure and new afib with RVR, now improving after intubation
   requiring pressors and a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic
   shock despite no positive cultures. Patient was extubated on [**12-17**],
   respiratory status improving, but refusing MVR surgery needed for full
   recovery.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Patient is improving from respiratory stand
   point, but remains deconditioned, making clearing her airway
   challenging and aspiration risk still significant. RR remains in mid
   20
s to upper 30
s on 3L O2 by NC with good oxygen saturation. Patient
   tolerating Lasix gtt at 10mg/hr well, meeting fluid goals.  Overall,
   while O2 can be weaned somewhat, patient appears to be nearing a
   plateau in regard to respiratory progress. As patient has decided not
   to proceed with MVR surgery, discussion should be had regarding plan
   for disposition (home vs. rehab) and expectations for rehabilitation.
   - Wean O2 as tolerates
   - keep HOB elevated
   - Out of bed to chair
   - standing Atrovent nebs
   - start rehab screening, need to discuss with patient
   - d/c doxy today today
   - last day of Acyclovir 400mg TID today
   - Continue TF (boost glucose control)
   - follow ABGs and respiratory status
   .
   # PHYSICAL DECONDITIONING: Patient has been in the hospital for 18
   days, intubated from [**Date range (1) 10393**].  Her extended period of immobility
   compounded by significant anasarca has left patient significantly
   deconditioned and as she is refusing surgery for mitral valve
   repair/replacement, it is unclear how much she will be able to
   rehabilitate from her current state. Physical therapy has begun working
   with her, but they are not able to provide the kind of intensive
   therapy that she would benefit from in a formal rehab facility.
   - start rehab screening, need to discuss with patient
   - continue PT/OT
   - encourage regular limb movement in bed
   - continue TF to gain nutrition and strength back
   .
   #. FLUID OVERLOAD: Anasarca [**1-10**] fluid imbalance (multifactorial:
   hypoalbuminemia/chronic sCHF/
leaky capillary syndrome
), slowly
   improving.  LOS fluid balance is approx 14L positive.  Patient
   diuresing on IV Lasix gtt with resulting hypernatremia & elevated HCO3
   from contraction alkalosis that is stable.
   -  Continue Lasix gtt at 5-10mg/hr.  Titrate to Goal UOP 100cc/hr, with
   goal I/O -500cc-1L today
   -  will need to transition to PO meds, likely tomorrow (torsemide for
   better oral bioavailability compared to lasix)

   -  MAP goal is 60-65
   .

   PUMP/SEVERE MR: Stable per TTE on [**12-16**], patient refusing MVR. Likely
   contributing to pulmonary status, but unclear how much is [**1-10**] fluid
   resuscitation and what is from mitral regurgitation at present.
   RHYTHM: Patient remains in AF.  Was on Amiodarone, discontinued
   yesterday since patient failed to convert on amiodarone. On Heparin gtt
   bridge to Coumadin. Continue Coumadin 2.5mg daily (goal INR [**1-11**]). Will
   D/C Heparin gtt when at goal. INR today 1.1.
   CORONARIES: No coronary history. Not an active issue on this admission.
   Continue ASA 81mg daily.
   .
   # INSOMNIA: Improved on Mirtazapine 15mg qHS without adverse side
   effects aside from residual somnolence this AM, but patient easily
   rousable.
   - Continue Mirtazapine 15mg qHS and Ativan 0.5mg qHS:PRN
   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with chronic systolic heart failure (sCHF), who was admitted to the ICU due to worsening heart failure, new-onset atrial fibrillation (AFib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR), and marked leukocytosis. She was intubated and required pressors to manage her condition. The patient has been in the hospital for 18 days and has been deconditioned due to immobility and anasarca (fluid accumulation).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: improving, but still deconditioned and at risk for aspiration
* Cardiovascular: stable, with AFib and severe mitral regurgitation (MR) requiring ongoing management
* Fluid overload: improving, but still positive fluid balance
* Leukocytosis: stable, with no signs of localized infection
* Anemia of inflammation: stable, with normocytic and normochromic anemia
* Possible right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT): being managed with heparin and Coumadin

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory distress: the patient's deconditioning and anasarca make her at risk for respiratory failure, and further deterioration may occur if not managed carefully.
2. Cardiovascular instability: the patient's AFib and severe MR require ongoing management to prevent cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
3. Fluid overload: the patient's positive fluid balance may lead to further complications, such as pulmonary edema or heart failure, if not managed carefully.
4. Leukocytosis: the patient's elevated white blood cell count may indicate an underlying infection or inflammatory process, which needs to be monitored and managed accordingly.
5. Anemia of inflammation: the patient's anemia may worsen if not managed with adequate iron and folate supplementation.
6. Right lower extremity DVT: the patient's possible DVT requires ongoing management with anticoagulation therapy to prevent further complications.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Manage the patient's cardiovascular condition with ongoing anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring of cardiac function.
3. Continue to manage the patient's fluid overload with diuretics and fluid restriction, and monitor electrolyte levels closely.
4. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further complications.
5. Continue to manage the patient's anemia of inflammation with iron and folate supplementation, and monitor hemoglobin levels closely.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's possible DVT with ongoing anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring of lower extremity function.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a 2-week history of generalized weakness and shortness of breath, who was admitted to the hospital with chronic systolic heart failure (EF >60%) and new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). She was intubated and required pressors and a marked leukocytosis, concerning for septic shock despite no positive cultures. She was extubated on [**12-17**] and is currently on a Lasix infusion at 10mg/hr. Her respiratory status is improving, but she remains deconditioned and has a significant anasarca.

The patient has been in the hospital for 18 days and has been immobile, which has contributed to her deconditioning. She is refusing mitral valve repair/replacement surgery, which is necessary for her full recovery. She is also experiencing insomnia, hypernatremia, metabolic alkalosis, and leukocytosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains deconditioned, which makes clearing her airway challenging and aspiration risk still significant.
2. Fluid Overload: The patient has a significant anasarca, which is multifactorial, including hypoalbuminemia, chronic systolic heart failure, and leaky capillary syndrome. She is currently on a Lasix infusion to diuresis, but her fluid balance is still positive.
3. Cardiac: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation, which is contributing to her pulmonary status. She is also at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation, and may require further treatment with digoxin.
4. Insomnia: The patient is experiencing insomnia, which is being treated with Mirtazapine and Ativan.
5. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has a stable metabolic alkalosis, which is being managed with Lasix and diamox.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient has a stable hypernatremia, which is being managed with TF and free water flushes.
7. Leukocytosis: The patient has a stable leukocytosis, which is being monitored with daily CBCs.
8. Anemia of Inflammation: The patient has a stable anemia of inflammation, which is being monitored with daily CBCs.
9. Right Lower Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a possible old DVT in the right posterior tibial veins, which is being managed with Heparin gtt and Coumadin.

Recommendations:

1. Continue Lasix infusion at 5-10mg/hr to diuresis and manage fluid overload.
2. Wean O2 as tolerated to prevent respiratory distress.
3. Monitor electrolytes and renal function closely to prevent hypernatremia and metabolic alkalosis.
4. Continue Heparin gtt and Coumadin to manage possible old DVT.
5. Monitor leukocytosis and anemia of inflammation with daily CBCs.
6. Consider outpatient repeat CT scan in 2 months to assess resolution of lymphadenopathy.
7. Continue home eye drops and Levothyroxine for glaucoma and hypothyroidism, respectively.
8. Consider physical therapy to improve patient's deconditioning and mobility.
9. Discuss plan for disposition (home vs. rehab) and expectations for rehabilitation with the patient.
